unnormalised: ## Rental Agreements: Your Guide to Avoiding Chai-Chai Later!
normalised: ## Rental Agreements: Your Guide to Avoiding Trouble Later!

unnormalised: Hey folks! So, you're looking to rent a place, maybe in bustling Bandra or chill Koramangala? Awesome! But before you hand over that security deposit (which can be hefty these days!), let's talk about the unsung hero of the rental world: the rental agreement.
normalised: Hey folks! So, you're looking to rent a place, maybe in bustling Bandra or chill Koramangala? Awesome! But before you hand over that security deposit (which can be hefty these days!), let's talk about the unsung hero of the rental world: the rental agreement.

unnormalised: Think of it like your marriage contract with your landlord. It spells out the "who, what, when, where, and how" of your living arrangement. Skipping this step is like going to a wedding without the pheras – things could get messy!
normalised: Think of it like your marriage contract with your landlord. It spells out the "who, what, when, where, and how" of your living arrangement. Skipping this step is like going to a wedding without the pheras – things could get messy!

unnormalised: First things first, make sure your agreement is in writing. A verbal agreement might sound sweet after a few cups of chai, but good luck proving anything if Mr. Sharma decides to suddenly raise the rent by Rs. 5000.
normalised: First things first, make sure your agreement is in writing. A verbal agreement might sound sweet after a few cups of tea, but good luck proving anything if Mister Sharma decides to suddenly raise the rent by rupee five thousand.

unnormalised: What should it include? Everything! Your rent amount (and when it's due, say 5th of every month), the security deposit (usually a few months' rent), the lease duration (typically 11 months to avoid complex registration hassles), and who's responsible for what. For example, who pays for the plumber if the tap starts leaking like a monsoon rain, or if the geyser decides to call it quits?
normalised: What should it include? Everything! Your rent amount (and when it's due, say fifth of every month), the security deposit (usually a a few months' rent), the lease duration (typically eleven months to avoid complex registration hassles), and who's responsible for what. For example, who pays for the plumber if the tap starts leaking like a monsoon rain, or if the geyser decides to call it quits?

unnormalised: Also, discuss about wear and tear vs. damage. Normal wear and tear (like fading paint) is generally on the landlord. Damage caused by you (like putting a hole in the wall after a particularly enthusiastic Diwali celebration) is usually your responsibility.
normalised: Also, discuss about wear and tear versus damage. Normal wear and tear (like fading paint) is generally on the landlord. Damage caused by you (like putting a hole in the wall after a particularly enthusiastic Diwali celebration) is usually your responsibility.

unnormalised: Don't forget to add details about the notice period. Usually, it's 30-60 days. Imagine wanting to leave suddenly to experience Onam in Kerala with your family and being stuck because of a vague agreement!
normalised: Don't forget to add details about the notice period. Usually, it's thirty to sixty days. Imagine wanting to leave suddenly to experience Onam in Kerala with your family and being stuck because of a vague agreement!

unnormalised: Before signing, read the document carefully. Don't be shy to ask questions! Is painting allowed? Can you keep pets? Is subletting okay? Get it all in black and white.
normalised: Before signing, read the document carefully. Don't be shy to ask questions! Is painting allowed? Can you keep pets? Is subletting okay? Get it all in black and white.

unnormalised: Finally, a well-crafted rental agreement will save you from headaches and potential disputes later on. It's like having a plate of delicious biryani after a long day – satisfying and reassuring! Happy renting! And remember to get it stamped! You can do that at any reputable place near the local court. Costs approx. Rs. 200 for the stamp paper and advocate fees might be another Rs. 1000-Rs. 2000. Don't try saving Rs.100 here.
